newsitem.title: UK: UK wheat surplus for exports put at 4.5 mln T.
newsitem.headline: UK wheat surplus for exports put at 4.5 mln T.

text.p: The UK may have nearly 4.5 million tonnes of wheat and 2.3 million of barley to export this season, according to estimates made by the Ministry of Agriculture (MAFF) on Tuesday.
The projected surpluses in 1996/97 (July/June) compare with last season's exports put at 3.0 million tonnes for wheat and 1.3 million for barley.

MAFF's first demand/supply estimates for the current season were based on a wheat harvest projection of 15.9 million tonnes, the highest for 10 years and compared with 14.3 million in 1995, and barley of 7.9 million tonnes from last year's 6.8 million.
Commenting on the MAFF figures, the Home-Grown Cereals Authority (HGCA) said large carryover stocks from last season had added to a bumper harvest gathered this year.

"UK wheat prices will have to maintain sufficient competitiveness for the increased supplies to find commercial markets, and prices are expected to be closer to intervention levels than over the past two seasons," HGCA said.
What complicates matters for producers in times of bumper crops is that there is no intervention on UK feed wheat which constitutes much of the wheat harvest.

MAFF estimated the total domestic wheat consumption one million tonnes higher at 12.749 million tonnes due to a sharp increase predicted in animal feed use. Barley use at home was estimated 200,000 tonnes lower at 5.7 million tonnes.
"Given that...apart from some early Saudi business, export prospects are not likely to dramatically improve, significant intervention offers are currently anticipated this season," said the HGCA.
The record rapeseed harvest of 1.49 million tonnes should help to cut the UK deficit in oilseed, reducing imports by more than half lasts season's total to 200,000 tonnes, it said.
UK grain prices have fallen dramatically since the beginning of the season due to a combination of bearish supply factors and a strong sterling.
